lexUnit.name: trouble.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: cause distress, pain, or inconvenience to

sentence.text: Some , like Frank Field , have been threatened with de-selection because their Christian consciences are troubled by the issue ; Labour for Life , an anti-abortion Left-wing group , has been ` de-recognised " by Walworth Road .
It was too dark and he was too afraid , or his conscience troubled him , or it was a combination of the two and so he hung back .
Beefy will report fit for today 's fourth Texaco Trophy clash with Pakistan , but skipper Graham Gooch said : ` It 's a problem which has troubled Ian for some time .
It was a question that troubled Saint Augustine : ` Whence is evil ?
To bypass , or not to bypass : that is the question troubling the people of north Norfolk .
But Subhadra 's question troubled her .
It is also a subject which has troubled the taller batsman .
He told me there was one thing which had deeply troubled him throughout his life , and that was refusing to acknowledge you when you were in trouble .
Marian talked over with him some of the things that troubled her .
He had asked her to talk to him about the things that troubled her , but she could not .
She looked , yes , the thought troubled him , like a woman .
I like not your being in the Tower -- it troubles me more than I could say ! "

The data do not prove that the operation precedes the bowel dysfunction , and it is possible that women who are troubled by the symptoms of constipation are more likely to report gynaecological symptoms to their general practitioners .
And Seve 's back was a real pain -- the cold got to it and it troubled him so much that we had to go and find a physiotherapist .
The players told him after the game that the lights did not trouble them as much as sunlight .
An elegant way to avoid these paradoxes that had so troubled Einstein was put forward by the American physicist Richard Feynman .

It troubled him that the common purpose , at least initially , would have to be beating the pulp out of Saladin ; but Richard was a realist as well as a dreamer , and knew that there always has to be a loser somewhere .
And now we find that the people who are troubling the Dales most at the moment are out of your own world -- Bragad and Jinneth .
Carbon dating for the Altamira caves , a penguin troubles sceptics at the submerged Grotte Henri Cosquer , and the sponge is a give-away at Alave
Charlton confessed : ` This one has been troubling me for some time .
Disputes with that Chesapeake neighbour would trouble the new Lord Baltimore for the remainder of his life .
The decision was an uncomfortable one which had troubled Ministers over several months and caused dissension in the Labour Party .

Terrible neuralgic pains which troubled him throughout this period were the mirror of his inward distress , and the large doses of laudanum he took to relieve his symptoms , a portent for the future .
It was the rock-bottom level of her own self-respect which troubled her .
Cornelius asked , for its proximity troubled him .
` Everything troubles me , Hal .
Many thinkers have been troubled by the problems implicit in the occurrence of pain and suffering .
I 'M sure there must be many people like me who have been troubled by telephone calls at ungodly hours which have turned out to be BT testing the lines .
The injury-prone Reid , who has been troubled by back and shoulder injuries throughout his career , will not be be able to train until early January .
I was initially troubled by a philosophical problem .
This paradox troubled Charles Darwin and he consulted Alfred Russell Wallace , who had ` an innate genius for solving difficulties " .
However , his putting has also troubled him and his first objective is to make the cut , which Ballesteros failed to do the year after both his victories .
The plucky Radford troubled Navratilova when they last met at Wimbledon four years ago , leading by a set and 3-1 before their match was suspended overnight .
Southey did not sleep well : Coleridge , evidently troubled by dreams even when his waking thoughts were optimistic , made a ` vile bedfellow " .
